description: This workspace will be used to store intents, entities & dialog flow

values:
For a calendar year‐end entity that adopts IFRS 15 in 2018, the date of equity adjustment for the different approaches are as follows:

Retrospective method (with or without practical expedients) – 1 January 2017

Cumulative effect method – 1 January 2018
For a calendar year‐end entity that adopts IFRS 15 in 2018, the date of equity adjustment for the Cumulative effect method is 1 January 2018
For a calendar year‐end entity that adopts IFRS 15 in 2018, the date of equity adjustment for the Retrospective method (with or without practical expedients) is 1 January 2017

An entity shall apply a single method of measuring progress for each performance obligation satisfied over time and the entity shall apply that method consistently to similar performance obligations and in similar circumstances. At the end of each reporting period, an entity shall remeasure its progress towards complete satisfaction of a performance obligation satisfied over time. Reference: IFRS 15.40

In some circumstances (for example, in the early stages of a contract), an entity may not be able to reasonably measure the outcome of a performance obligation, but the entity expects to recover the costs incurred in satisfying the performance obligation. In those circumstances, the entity shall recognise revenue only to the extent of the costs incurred until such time that it can reasonably measure the outcome of the performance obligation.Reference: IFRS 15.45

For each performance obligation satisfied over time in accordance with paragraphs 35–37 of IFRS 15, an entity shall recognise revenue over time by measuring the progress towards complete satisfaction of that performance obligation. The objective when measuring progress is to depict an entity's performance in transferring control of goods or services promised to a customer (i.e. the satisfaction of an entity's performance obligation). Reference: IFRS 15.39

Performance obligations do not include activities that an entity must undertake to fulfil a contract unless those activities transfer a good or service to a customer. For example, a services provider may need to perform various administrative tasks to set up a contract. The performance of those tasks does not transfer a service to the customer as the tasks are performed. Therefore, those setup activities are not a performance obligation. Reference: IFRS 15.25

The date of initial application is the start of the reporting period in which an entity first applies IFRS 15. Hence, it will remain the same regardless of the election of transition options (i.e. cumulative or retrospective method, with or without practical expedient). Reference: IFRS 15.C2(a)
Retrospective and Cumulative effect methods
Yes, IFRS 15 modifies IFRS 1 to allow retrospective application with practical expedients. Reference: IFRS 1.D34‐D35

For a calendar year‐end entity that adopts IFRS 15 in 2018, the date of equity adjustment for the different approaches are as follows:Retrospective method (with or without practical expedients) – 1 January 2017Cumulative effect method – 1 January 2018. Reference: IFRS 15.C3

Under the cumulative effect method, an entity can choose to apply the requirements of the new standard to:-  Only contracts that are not completed contracts at the date of initial application; or-  All contracts at the date of initial application.An entity that applied the cumulative effect method may also use the contract modifications practical expedient for all contract modifications that occur before the beginning of the earliest period presented or for all contract modifications that occur before the date of initial application. Reference: IFRS 1.C7A

Under IFRS, a completed contract is a contract for which the entity has transferred all of the goods or services identified in accordance with IAS 11 Construction Contracts, IAS 18 Revenue and related Interpretations. Reference: IFRS 15.C2(b)

Considering the fact that the installation service does not significantly modify or customise the software itself, the software and the installation service are separate outputs promised by the entity instead of inputs used to produce a combined output. The two are not highly integrated or interrelated and as such they are likely to form 2 separate performance obligations. Reference: IFRS 15. IE51

For a calendar year‐end entity that adopts IFRS 15 in 2018, the date of equity adjustment for the different approaches are as follows: 

Retrospective method (with or without practical expedients) – 1 January 2017
Cumulative effect method – 1 January 2018

Reference: IFRS 15.C3

Which method ?
Retrospective method
Cumulative effect method
or Both
The date of initial application is the start of the reporting period in which an entity first applies IFRS 15.  Reference: IFRS 15.C2(a)
Under US GAAP, a completed contract is a contract for which an entity has recognized all (or substantially all) of the revenue under current US GAAP.  Reference: 606‐10‐65‐1c(2)
A practical expedient is an optional application relief allowed by IFRS 15 for entities that are transitioning into the standard.

Considering the fact that the installation service does not significantly modify or customise the software itself, the software and the installation service are separate outputs promised by the entity instead of inputs used to produce a combined output. The two are not highly integrated or interrelated and as such they are likely to form 2 separate performance obligations. Reference: IFRS 15. IE51

The term IP is not defined in the new revenue standard, nor elsewhere in IFRS. In some cases, it will be clear that an arrangement includes a license of IP – e.g. a trademark. In other cases, such as when content is being made available to a customer over the internet, it may be less clear and the accounting may be different depending on that determination. Therefore, an entity may need to apply judgment to determine whether the guidance on licenses applies to an arrangement.

Examples of IP licenses include:* Software and technology* Franchises* Patents, trademarks and copyrights* Movies, music and video games* Scientific compounds * Reference: IFRS 15.B52; KPMG Issues in Depth Second Edition May 2016, 8.1
Hope I was able to answer your questions, have a good day!

IFRS 1 generally requires retrospective application of IFRSs in the opening IFRS statement of financial position, the comparative period and the first IFRS reporting period, other than the application of mandatory exceptions and optional exemptions from the retrospective application requirements. Hence, the cumulative effect method would not be applicable for a first‐time adopter of IFRS.IFRS 15 modifies IFRS 1 to allow retrospective application with practical expedients. IFRS 1.7, 1.D34‐D35
If an entity applies one or more practical expedients, then it needs to do so consistently for all goods and services for all periods presented. Reference: IFRS 15.C6

At the end of each reporting period, an entity shall update the estimated transaction price (including updating its assessment of whether an estimate of variable consideration is constrained) to represent faithfully the circumstances present at the end of the reporting period and the changes in circumstances during the reporting period. The entity shall account for changes in the transaction price in accordance with paragraphs 87–90. Reference: IFRS 15.59

The new standard includes specific guidance on the following: 

* Costs of obtaining a contract. 
* Costs of fulfilling a contract 
* Impairment of assets arising from costs to obtain or fulfill a contract 
* Amortisation of assets arising from costs to obtain or fulfill a contract

If a performance obligation is not satisfied over time in accordance with paragraphs 35–37, an entity satisfies the performance obligation at a point in time. To determine the point in time at which a customer obtains control of a promised asset and the entity satisfies a performance obligation, the entity shall consider the requirements for control in paragraphs 31–34. In addition, an entity shall consider indicators of the transfer of control, which include, but are not limited to, the following: The entity has a present right to payment for the asset 
 The customer has legal title to the asset 
 The entity has transferred physical possession of the asset 
 The customer has the significant risks and rewards of ownership of the asset 
 The customer has accepted the asset Reference: IFRS 15.38
Hi, How I can help you today?

An entity capitalises incremental costs to obtain a contract with a customer, if it expects to recover those costs. However, as a practical expedient, an entity is not required to capitalise the incremental costs to obtain a contract if the amortization period for the asset is one year or less. Reference: IFRS 15.91‐92‐94; KPMG Issues in Depth Second Edition May 2016, 6.1
